rules.rule_text: Avoid ambiguities in translations.
Maintain a unified style across translations.
Understand and address expectations for translations.
Do not treat the guide as a complete list of grammar rules.
Focus on ambiguities, customization, frequent errors, and problematic issues in translations.
Use full-width punctuation for hyphenated terms (e.g., �rst → first).
Do not translate product names (e.g., JIRA).
Do not translate product names.
Avoid using a negative or frightening tone in translations.
examples_pos: Use a positive and reassuring tone
examples_neg: Use a negative or frightening tone

rules.rule_text: Use active voice in translations.
examples_neg: The project was completed by the team

rules.rule_text: Localization should adapt the text to the target language, customs, and standards.
When translating editorial content, aim to achieve the same results as in the original.
examples_pos: Translation that matches the original tone
examples_neg: Neutralized or omitted content in translation

rules.rule_text: When presented with a list of languages/countries not sorted alphabetically in the source, reorder the list items to place the target language first.
Headings and subheadings should be informative and descriptive.
Headings and subheadings should highlight the most important concept or piece of information for merchants.
Headings and subheadings should help merchants understand what they’ll find in the section below.
Headings and subheadings should be concise and scannable.
Headings and subheadings should use simple, clear language.
Headings and subheadings should keep to a single sentence.
Headings and subheadings should avoid using punctuation such as periods, commas, or semicolons.
The translation should be crisp and appealing to the reader.
Keep the subject line short and concise.
Present tense is preferred. Only use future tense when referring to something that'll happen in the future.
examples_pos: After this date, the boosted post will revert to a regular post.
examples_neg: After this date, the boosted post will revert to a regular post.

rules.rule_text: Use the right tone. An instructional, informal and direct tone is preferred.
Use contractions.
examples_pos: After you’ve set up your product, click Save.
examples_neg: After you have set up your product, click Save.

rules.rule_text: Address the reader or user as “you.”
examples_pos: You can add products from the Products page in your Shopify admin.

rules.rule_text: Use variable sentence structure in translation.
Avoid long sentences in translation.
Avoid using more than two “的” in one sentence.
examples_neg: Include more than two “的” in a sentence.

rules.rule_text: Legal translation must be 100% accurate and faithful to the original text.
The legal translator must ensure that the translated document conveys the same meaning as the original document.
The translator must be familiar with the legal systems and terminology of both the source and target languages.
The translator must be able to convey the intended meaning of the legal document in the cultural context of the target language.
Write shorter translations for captions. Prioritize conveying the original meaning and intent while keeping Shopify’s voice and values in mind.
Observe character limit: refer to project-specific information if available or follow the length limits as stated.
Adjust caption length (duration) if needed, e.g., when there’s not enough time to read a caption in the target language.
Keep the verb conjugation / way of address as in the original wherever it makes sense.
Contrary to English, Simplified Chinese has no verb conjugation, but tense must be reflected in the translation.
Text should match the actions/video displays presented in the video.
Sometimes, change the sequence of sentences for readability. However, follow the sequence of the source when translating subtitles to keep consistency between text and video displays if possible.
Avoid ending a sentence and starting a new one in the same subtitle, except for short sentences and instances where it makes sense to do so.
examples_neg: Subtitle ends sentence, starts new one.

rules.rule_text: Use separate subtitles for each sentence, or several subtitles in case of long sentences.
End subtitles at natural linguistic breakpoints: after punctuation marks, before conjunctions, before prepositions.
The line break should not separate: a noun from an article, a noun from an adjective, a first name from a last name, a verb from a subject pronoun.
examples_pos: First name and last name in same subtitle.
examples_neg: First name and last name split.

rules.rule_text: Avoid creating acronyms.
If you have to use an acronym, spell it out the first time you use it and follow with the acronym in brackets.
examples_pos: The Rich Text Editor (RTE) is a powerful tool.
examples_neg: The RTE is a powerful tool.

rules.rule_text: Internationally understood acronyms and abbreviations are acceptable.
examples_pos: Use internationally understood acronyms like 'time zone' (TZ), 'tax', etc.

rules.rule_text: If an English acronym is to be used throughout a text, the first time it occurs, follow this structure: [Acronym] (e.g., RTE).
examples_pos: The Rich Text Editor (RTE) is a powerful tool.

rules.rule_text: Do not capitalize Chinese characters.
Capitalize English characters in proper nouns as per the original format.
Translate job titles and team names in running text.
examples_neg: "Ecosystem Governance" appears in the signature of the email below, which should not be translated.

rules.rule_text: Do not translate job titles and team names in signatures.
examples_neg: "Ecosystem Governance" appears in the signature of the email below, which should not be translated.

rules.rule_text: Avoid using punctuation such as periods, commas, or semicolons in translations.
Follow the source punctuation.
Do not add a period after single-word or noun phrase items in the translation.
Use Chinese full stop at the end of a sentence, even when it ends with an English word, numeral or URL.
examples_neg: 句子以数字或URL结尾时用英文句号。

rules.rule_text: Avoid using a full stop at the end of a line in Chinese marketing headlines and subheads.
In creative advertising, a full stop at the end of a line may be acceptable as a graphic treatment or artistic consideration.
If commas are used to separate keywords, always use single-byte commas because they function as operators.
examples_neg: If commas are used to separate keywords, always use double-byte commas because they function as operators.

rules.rule_text: In Chinese, the em dash (—) should not be used as it looks the same as the Chinese character for 'one' (一).
examples_neg: The em dash (—) is used here.

rules.rule_text: If punctuation is needed in Chinese, use ( ), ：or en dash to emphasize the element.
As for the standard Chinese dash “——”, no space is needed.
examples_pos: Standard Chinese dash “——” is used without space.
examples_neg: Standard Chinese dash “—— ” is used with space.

rules.rule_text: If the single byte English dash is used in Chinese, it depends on context.
examples_pos: Use single byte English dash if context allows.
examples_neg: Always use single byte English dash in Chinese.

rules.rule_text: Understand the cultural context of both source and target audiences to avoid misunderstandings or potential offense.
Consider the surrounding text when translating emojis to ensure they fit appropriately.
Strive to preserve the emotional intent of the original emoji when translating.
Use the most appropriate expressions in the target language to convey the intended meaning effectively.
Dates must be rewritten according to Chinese style using YYYY 年 MM 月 DD 日 or YYYY 年 M 月 D 日.
Time format must use 'XXhXX' (24-hour clock) with single-byte colon (:) as separator.
AM/PM must be translated to 上午 and 下午 respectively.
Always check project specific instructions for currency handling.
Currency symbols, values (roughly convert if not 1 to 1 with USD$), and currency codes must be localized.
Always assess the context at hand against the definition when using approved terminology.
Never follow the termbase blindly if a term is used in a different context.
Use industry-standard terminology.
Follow spelling and capitalization of Shopify brand names as well as third-party brand names.
Shopify prefers descriptive names for its products. Verify there is no confusion with the corresponding common noun, especially when the term is capitalized.
Product names are usually not translated, while feature names are.
Refer to the Terminology guidelines for the localization of proper nouns.
examples_neg: Do not refer to Terminology guidelines for proper nouns.

rules.rule_text: Translators & reviewers must proactively raise terminology-related queries in the JIRA Language Forum.
examples_neg: Do not raise terminology queries in JIRA.

rules.rule_text: Language Specialists must use QuickTerm and the Query Sheet to raise terminology queries from translators and themselves with the client.
examples_neg: Do not use QuickTerm or Query Sheet for terminology queries.

rules.rule_text: Enter a new term request in the Query Sheet and directly in QuickTerm whenever a new term or deviation from standard language is used in the source text.
examples_neg: Do not enter new term requests in QuickTerm or Query Sheet.

rules.rule_text: When a new or challenging term is solved in a language, share the outcome with all other languages.
examples_neg: Do not share term solutions with other languages.

rules.rule_text: Double-check terms marked as Legacy, in particular: product, plan, and program names.
Shopify product names are Do Not Translate (DNT) terms.
Do not translate the name portion of an API.
Move around API, the part of the name indicating the category so as to conform to each target language’s grammatical rules.
Refer to the Terminology guidelines for the localization of proper nouns.
Shopify can be occasionally omitted from the product name.
Always check Shopify’s latest TB.
Do not translate third-party product names unless they are specified by Shopify.
examples_neg: Do not translate 'Shopify' in any context

rules.rule_text: Trademarked names and registered trademarks should not be localized unless local laws require translation, and an approved translated form of the trademark is available.
For third-party trademarks, verify how the names are treated on the third party’s website.
Ask the question to the query sheet in case of doubt.
examples_neg: Do not ask the query sheet.

rules.rule_text: Text in curly brackets should not be translated unless otherwise instructed.
Check any project specific information regarding translation of curly bracketed text.
It is OK to move the placeholder around in curly bracketed text.
Text in angle brackets should not be translated unless otherwise instructed.
Text in square brackets should not be translated unless project-specific information or context indicates otherwise.
Do not add spaces between the ending square bracket of the anchor text and the round bracket of the URL.
examples_neg: Discover our what is dropshipping ({{blog, url(path: '/what-is-dropshipping')}})

rules.rule_text: UI texts should be clear, concise, and consistent.
When encountering a UI item, check if it has been already translated to maintain consistency.
If a UI had been already localized, then it should be available in the TM and that translation can be used.
If you do not find the UI item in the Admin TM, then it hasn't been localized yet (it might belong to an app or software that has not been localized).
In Help projects, use the bilingual format <possible tag>English<\possible tag> (Translation) to refer to the correct English UI.
When translating UI options, distinguish buttons from CTA links.
Buttons: Omit articles and unnecessary pronouns to reduce characters in the button text.
CTA links: Use articles in order to improve the readability and naturalness of the sentence. Omit articles only when reducing the length of the string.
As a general rule, don’t use quotation marks to refer to a UI option.
Capitalization is not relevant for Simplified Chinese. Pay attention to the correct capitalization of terms left in English.
Buttons and UI options are written in the infinitive form (command actions, button names and links).
Do not insert additional line breaks into translation (in Smartling displayed as �).
If there is a line break in the suggestion from the TM and there are no line breaks in the source, delete that additional line break.
examples_neg: Line break in translation but not source
